word.entryDescription: (also 'hippie') relating to or characteristic of hippies
word.entryExample: The hippie movement originated in the United States.

word.entryDescription: (also 'hippie') a member of a subculture that emerged in the United States during the 1960s; hippies rejected established social customs and opposed violence and war peacefully
word.entryExample: Hippies wore flared jeans or long dresses and long, beaded necklaces.

word.entryDescription: to pay money to borrow something for a short period of time; to rent
word.entryExample: Hundreds of bicycles are hired every day.

word.entryDescription: the study of past events
word.entryExample: She would like to study Japanese history.

word.entryDescription: a place where things are very busy
word.entryExample: There is a hive of activity on the new housing estate because the first residents are arriving very soon.

word.entryDescription: an activity that you regularly do in your free time for pleasure
word.entryExample: Can you tell me about your hobby, Lucy?

word.entryDescription: a team sport in which people try to hit a ball or puck into a goal using sticks
word.entryExample: Which hockey team do you support?

word.entryDescription: to remain in a position in which a part of your body you are exercising is stretched
word.entryExample: For each exercise, hold the stretch for a few seconds, then relax.

word.entryDescription: to stay strong and not separate into different parts
word.entryExample: Wrapping is enough to hold together simple skirts.

word.entryDescription: to block or delay somebody/something
word.entryExample: We've been held up by this huge traffic jam for hours.

word.entryDescription: stop breathing for a short time
word.entryExample: Keep doing this until you feel calm, but don't pause or hold your breath.

word.entryDescription: a period of time when you are not working and you can rest or go to another place to enjoy yourself
word.entryExample: Where did you go on holiday last year?

word.entryDescription: someone who goes on holidays
word.entryExample: This area is popular with holidaymakers.

word.entryDescription: the place where you live or feel you belong
word.entryExample: Does your dad cook at home?

word.entryDescription: not having anywhere to live
word.entryExample: The homeless victims of wars and natural disasters end up in refugee camps.

word.entryDescription: the initial or main web page of a website
word.entryExample: Then I need to log in to the company homepage.

word.entryDescription: reading and writing the teacher gives you to do at home
word.entryExample: I do my homework after school.

word.entryDescription: truthful and able to be trusted
word.entryExample: Oh, you have to be quite tactful if a customer asks what they look like in an outfit, but it’s important to be honest as well.

word.entryDescription: a sweet food made by bees
word.entryExample: I need some flour, an onion, some honey and some bananas.

word.entryDescription: a sweatshirt with a hood
word.entryExample: In the picture, I’m wearing my tracksuit bottoms with a hooded sweatshirt.

word.entryDescription: a device for fastening clothes, consisting of a small metal ring, and a hook that fits into it
word.entryExample: Hooks and eyes can be used with tightly laced clothes.

word.entryDescription: a nose shaped like a hook; curved
word.entryExample: I've got a hooked nose like a bird's beak.

word.entryDescription: to jump using only one leg
word.entryExample: In the evening the frogs hop into the pound.

word.entryDescription: a positive feeling about something that you want to happen
word.entryExample: They have given up hope of finding a new cure for this illness.

word.entryDescription: something that seems to be a line in the distance separating the Earth from the sky
word.entryExample: The ship sailed away and disappeared over the horizon.

word.entryDescription: something tak makes you frightened or shocked
word.entryExample: We watched in horror as the car crashed.

word.entryDescription: a large animal with four legs and long hair over its neck. People ride horses, or use them pulling things.
word.entryExample: The horse's name is Sandy.

word.entryDescription: a large balloon filled with hot air or gas to make it rise in the air, usually with a basket for carrying passengers
word.entryExample: Would you like to fly in a hot air balloon over the desert?

word.entryDescription: a building in which you can book a room for the night
word.entryExample: William is going to stay at a hotel.

word.entryDescription: plural of 'hour' – a period of 60 minutes
word.entryExample: This film is three hours long.

word.entryDescription: a single building in which people live
word.entryExample: She lives in a littte house with a red door.

word.entryDescription: a boat that you can live in usually kept at a particular place on a river
word.entryExample: If you live in a houseboat, you have to live in remote places, away from people.

word.entryDescription: a group of people who live together in one home
word.entryExample: The pace of building is going to have to accelerate to meet the needs of new households.

word.entryDescription: an area of homes that were planned and built together
word.entryExample: There is a hive of activity on the new housing estate because the first residents are arriving very soon.

word.entryDescription: used with a statement which seems surprising or different in contrast to the previous one; nevertheless
word.entryExample: Many people are in favour of the death penalty. However, there are many examples of people being found guilty and then, years later, being found innocent.

word.entryDescription: a person
word.entryExample: These plants are often really useful for humans as they contain medicines that can be used to treat fever, burns, pain and breathing problems.

word.entryDescription: (of air) warm and containing a lot of water or water vapour
word.entryExample: It's hot and humid in the Amazon rainforest.

word.entryDescription: the state of being humid, or the amount of water vapour in the air
word.entryExample: It's difficult to dry our clothes because of the humidity.

word.entryDescription: when you are hungry you need to eat food
word.entryExample: I'm hungry. Can I have a sandwich?

word.entryDescription: to chase and kill wild animals
word.entryExample: Men sometimes wear weapons even if they don't hunt or fight.

word.entryDescription: the activity of finding and killing wild animals for food or sport
word.entryExample: Some animals have been killed by people hunting them for their skin, meat, feathers or eggs.

word.entryDescription: an extremely windy storm that often causes a lot of damage
word.entryExample: Hurricanes carry water from the oceans.

word.entryDescription: to feel or cause pain
word.entryExample: I can't go to school, my leg hurts so much.

word.entryDescription: the practice of keeping things clean in order to prevent disease
word.entryExample: The Japanese, who are very attentive to hygiene, live the longest.

word.entryDescription: an idea or explanation of something which has not yet been proved to be true
word.entryExample: They try to explain the results of the experiment and see if it follows their hypothesis.

word.entryDescription: I understand what you are saying.
word.entryExample: I see your point, but I don't agree.

word.entryDescription: frozen water
word.entryExample: If you put salt on ice it turns to water.

word.entryDescription: a very cold sweet food made from frozen milk, sugar and flavour
word.entryExample: At the beach we all have an ice cream.

word.entryDescription: a team sport in which people try to hit a ball into a goal using sticks
word.entryExample: Kate is going to play in an ice hockey match.

word.entryDescription: an ice cream or water ice on a stick
word.entryExample: Yum! I've wanted an ice lolly all day!
